Blog.post: urlLink press release It has been a long time that I have been planning to buy a GPS. The last time I cursed myself for not having bought one was approximatively a month ago when I went to Germany for a "business trip": I had to go to urlLink Kalsruhe and going by train or plane would have taken as long as going by car, so I took the "rig". Going there should not have been a problem: I used a urlLink trip planning web site . Practically, however, it was quite difficult to read the map while driving. Once you are on a highway, it is psychologically difficult to exit to "nowhere" (because your trip planner itinerary says so) whereas your final destination is announced further away on the road you are about to leave. I quickly realized that staying on that highway would cost me 100 Kilometers more... But I did! I finally arrived with an extra 40 minutes on the chrono and luckily found, in less than 10 minutes, the hotel where my room was booked... When I headed back home, things were a bit different: I had not printed the "reverse trip" and had no access to the Internet anymore. My only clues were my paper map and the compass that is built in my car. Total tally: 170 Km and 2 hours more than it should have been... Right now, I am slowly putting some money aside to buy one of those GPS asap, hence my interest in the press release above.

I cannot stress this enough. I am currently in the process of gathering all the proofs about what is said in my resume and it is a damn painfull process. My current employer (international organisation) will give me a 3 to 4 years contract but he is asking for everything . So follow this advice: keep all the following kind of documents, put somewhere safe and scan them as soon as you receive them: Diplomas Military service papers Any kind of attestation saying that you have done something for a certain period of time Engagement contracts Salary files Make sure that you have a copy for everything that you put in your resume.
